message_1: Suppose a baker has three cake orders with requirements as follows: the first order requires 5 layers, the second order requires 7 layers, and the third order requires 9 layers. The baker can only bake cakes with a maximum of 10 layers each. Using the Chinese remainder theorem, what is the smallest number of cakes the baker needs to make to fulfill all three orders?
message_2:
Let's use the Chinese remainder theorem to solve this problem. Let x be the number of cakes the baker needs to make. We have the following congruences:

x ≡ 5 (mod 10) for the first order
x ≡ 7 (mod 10) for the second order
x ≡ 9 (mod 10) for the third order

Since the moduli are all the same (10), we can combine the congruences into a single congruence:

x ≡ 5 + 7 + 9 (mod 10)
x ≡ 21 (mod 10)

Since 21 ≡ 1 (mod 10), we have:

x ≡ 1 (mod 10)

This means that the smallest number of cakes the baker needs to make is 1 more than a multiple of 10. The smallest such number is 11. Therefore, the baker needs to make at least 11 cakes to fulfill all three orders.
